title: How to Prevent Soggy Pastry Bases

steps.headline: Make the pastry in a cool, clean environment free of wet surfaces.
steps.description: Dry everything before rolling your pastry, and be careful to keep your hands, implements, and surfaces cool at all times. Consider chilling pastry for at least an hour prior to working with it; this helps it to dry out and makes it easier to handle quickly.

steps.headline: Allow all fillings to cool before adding.
steps.description: Hot and even warm fillings will create steam and moisture that will have nowhere to go but into the pastry. The pastry will reward you with sogginess. Only add cold fillings when making filled pastries.

steps.headline: Remove excess moisture.
steps.description: There is nowhere for filling to go inside pastry except into the pastry. Excess moisture in a filling will create soggy pastry. Drain moist fillings, or prefer fillings that do not present a moisture challenge.

steps.headline: Use slits for pies.
steps.description: Pies and pastries with dense fruit or moist veggie fillings will benefit from slits to let out the steam escape during cooking.

steps.headline: Aim to place your pastry or pie in the lower third of the oven.
steps.description: The idea behind this is to provide adequate time for base cooking without over-browning the top. Alternately, add aluminum foil to the top to prevent fast browning while the base cooks thoroughly.

steps.headline: Consider blind baking the pastry first.
steps.description: This will often take care of the problem of a soggy base. However, this will not allow you to add a hot filling! There remains a need to always use cold filling, blind baked or not.

steps.headline: Provide plenty of ventilation when cooling.
steps.description: If you allow your pastry to cool in its bake ware with nowhere for the heat to escape but into the pastry, it is possible that you will end up with soggy pastry post-cooking but be guided by the recipe and remove the pastry from the pastry pan/dish if and when the recipe asks you to do so. Allow the pastry to cool on a wire cooling rack.

Only add cold fillings when making filled pastries. Remove excess moisture. There is nowhere for filling to go inside pastry except into the pastry. Pies and pastries with dense fruit or moist veggie fillings will benefit from slits to let out the steam escape during cooking. Aim to place your pastry or pie in the lower third of the oven. The idea behind this is to provide adequate time for base cooking without over-browning the top. Alternately, add aluminum foil to the top to prevent fast browning while the base cooks thoroughly. Consider blind baking the pastry first. This will often take care of the problem of a soggy base. However, this will not allow you to add a hot filling! There remains a need to always use cold filling, blind baked or not. Provide plenty of ventilation when cooling.
